facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 97 of 1961 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 97 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated February 1, 1961 of Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench in Criminal Appeal No. 403 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 1, 1961, of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  Lucknow in Criminal Appeal No. 403 of 1960.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court confirmed judgment of Additional Sessions Judge, Kheri convicting appellant under s. 218 IPC and sentencing to two years rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: P. Sinha and Saukat Hussain, for the appellant. C. Mathur and C. P. Lal. for the respondent. 1962. November 13. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.-This is an appeal by Special leave against the judgment and order of the Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench, confirming that of the Additional Sessions judge, Kheri, convicting the appellant under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code and sentencing him to two, years rigorous im- prisonment.

facts.text: Appellant is a Police Head Constable.

anchor.surface_text: Chauhan in order to create evidence in his favour got a report entered by the appellant, a Police Head- constable in the General diary of the Police Station

facts.text: Railway officers including Chauhan, Railway Guard, went on two trollies towards Bhitra for a shoot.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case may be briefly stated - Some Railway officers and others, including one Chauhan, Railway Guard, went on two trollies towards Bhitra for a shoot.

facts.text: Chauhan had a double barrelled gun of twelve bore bearing No. 23727.

anchor.surface_text: Chauhan had with him a double barrelled gun of twelve bore bearing No. 23727.

facts.text: Appellant entered a report in General Diary of Police Station purporting to be taken on December 13, 1956 at 6.45 PM that Chauhan deposited the gun.

anchor.surface_text: Chauhan in order to create evidence in his favour got a report entered by the appellant, a Police Head- constable in the General diary of the Police Station purporting to have been taken on December 13, 1956, at 6.45 M. to the effect that Chauhan had deposited the said gun in the Police Station.

facts.text: Appellant made many other manipulations in Police record to conform with the false entry.

anchor.surface_text: Many other manipulations were made by the appellant in the Police record to bring it in conformity with the said false entry.

facts.text: Several persons including Chauhan and appellant prosecuted under ss. 304-A, 201/109, 120-B, 218/109 IPC and s.26 Indian Forest Act.

anchor.surface_text: Several persons, including Chauhan and the appellant were prosecuted under ss. 304-A, 201/109, 120-B and 218/109 of the Indian Penal Code, as. well under s. 26 of the Indian Forest Act, and they were tried by the Additional Sessions Judge, Kheri.

facts.text: All accused acquitted except appellant convicted under s.218 IPC and sentenced to two years RI by Additional Sessions Judge, Kheri.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was also charged under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code. All the accused were acquitted except the appellant who was convicted under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced to two years rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: Appellant's appeal to High Court dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal filed by him to the High Court was dismissed. Hence this present appeal.

facts.text: Two persons Ramdeo and Chhotey shot dead.

anchor.surface_text: Two persons were shot dead.

facts.text: Gun shot injuries to Ramdeo and Chhotey likely received between 7-20 to 7-40 PM on night between December 14 and 15, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The medical evidence does number say about the duration of the gun shot injuries of Ramdeo and Chhotey but from the above numbered discussion of the evidence it would appear that Ramdeo and Chhotey were likely to have received gun-shot injuries between 7-20 to 7-40 P.M. in the night between December, 14 and 15, 1956.

facts.text: Three guns with the party including Chauhan's gun.

anchor.surface_text: the learned Additional Sessions judge found that the following facts had been established - That there were three guns with the party, including Chauhans gun

facts.text: Between miles 8 and 9 trollies stopped and placed by side of track, Ramdeo trolly man and Lala went away, shortly four gun-shots heard, Lala returned alone.

anchor.surface_text: That between miles 8 and 9 after the trollies were stopped and were placed by the side of, the track, Ramdeo trolly man and Lala went away and shortly after that four gun-shots were heard and shortly after that Lala returned alone

facts.text: Party except Ramdeo returned to Mailani by Cane Special.

anchor.surface_text: and then all the members of the party excepting Ramdeo returned to Mailani by the Cane Special,

facts.text: At time of shots, Chauhan and Gupta standing near track with guns in hands, Dilawar, Amin and Hira standing by side of track.

anchor.surface_text: That at the time when the four gun-shots were heard, Chauhan and Gupta were standing just near the track with their guns in their hands and, Dilawar, Amin and Hira also remained standing by the side of the track.

facts.text: No direct or substantial evidence connecting any of five accused including Chauhan with death of Ramdeo and Chhotey.

anchor.surface_text: From the foregoing facts found the learned Judge came to the conclusion that there was number direct or substantial evidence of any kind connecting any of the five accused, including Chauhan, with the death of Ramdeo and Chhotey.

facts.text: Prosecution against appellant launched three months after the entry alleged to be made by him.

anchor.surface_text: the second that the prosecution against the appellant having been launched three months after the entry is alleged to have been made by him in the Police diary

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on November 13, 1962 by SUBBA RAO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. November 13. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.-This is an appeal by Special leave against the judgment and order of the Allahabad High Court,

facts.text: Appellant argued acquittal of Chauhan means charge under s.218 should fall.

anchor.surface_text: The first was-that as Chauhan was acquitted of all the offences with which he was charged, the charge against the appellant under. s. 218, Indian Penal Code, should fall with it

facts.text: Appellant argued prosecution barred by limitation under s.42 Police Act.

anchor.surface_text: was barred by limitation under s. 42 of the Police Act.

facts.text: Chauhan acquitted of all charges including s.218/109 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Chauhan had been charged along with the appellant for offences under SS. 304-A, 120-B, 201/109 and 218/109 of the Indian, Penal Code and s. 26 of the Indian Forest Act. He was acquitted.

facts.text: Court found appellant manipulated record with intent to save Chauhan from legal punishment.

anchor.surface_text: the mere acquittal of Chauhan cannot displace the finding of the learned Judge that the appellant manipulated the record with an intent thereby to save or knowing it to be likely that he would thereby save Chauhan from legal punishment.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds conviction of appellant not inconsistent with acquittal of Chauhan.

anchor.surface_text: We,, therefore, hold that the conviction of the appellant is number inconsistent with the acquittal of Chauhan.
under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code

issues.text: whether, as Chauhan was acquitted of all the offences with which he was charged, the charge against the appellant under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code should fall with it

anchor.surface_text: The first was-that as Chauhan was acquitted of all the offences with which he was charged, the charge against the appellant under. s. 218, Indian Penal Code, should fall with it

issues.text: whether the prosecution against the appellant having been launched three months after the entry is alleged to have been made by him in the Police diary was barred by limitation under s. 42 of the Police Act

anchor.surface_text: and the second that the prosecution against the appellant having been launched three months after the entry is alleged to have been made by him in the Police diary was barred by limitation under s. 42 of the Police Act.

anchor.surface_text: The first was-that as Chauhan was acquitted of all the offences with which he was charged, the charge against the appellant under. s. 218, Indian Penal Code, should fall with it

arguments.court_reasoning: Acquittal of Chauhan does not displace finding that appellant acted with intent to save Chauhan from punishment at time of fabrication when prosecution was likely; conviction under s.218 independent of subsequent acquittal

arguments.claim: The prosecution against the appellant having been launched three months after the entry is alleged to have been made by him in the Police diary was barred by limitation under s. 42 of the Police Act

anchor.surface_text: and the second that the prosecution against the appellant having been launched three months after the entry is alleged to have been made by him in the Police diary was barred by limitation under s. 42 of the Police Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the record by the appellant with a view to save Chauhan. Whether the acquittal of Chauhan was companyrect or number, the companyviction of the appell

arguments.court_reasoning: s.42 applies only to prosecutions for acts done under Police Act or general police powers, not to offences under IPC like s.218; s.36 confirms Police Act does not preclude prosecution under other Acts

arguments.claim: Crux of s.218 IPC is that public servant acted with intent thereby to save or knowing likely to save any person from legal punishment

anchor.surface_text: The crux of the section so far as it is relevant to the present inquiry is that the public servant should have acted in the manner contemplated by this section with an intent thereby to save or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby save any person from legal, punishment.

arguments.claim: At time false entries made, every likelihood of Chauhan being prosecuted for causing deaths

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, manifest that whether Chauhan was guilty or not, at the time the false entries were made in the case diary there was every likelihood of Chauhan being prosecuted along with others for causing the death of Ramdeo and Chotey.

arguments.claim: Mere acquittal of Chauhan cannot displace finding that appellant manipulated record with intent to save Chauhan from legal punishment

anchor.surface_text: On the said facts the mere acquittal of Chauhan cannot displace the finding of the learned Judge that the appellant manipulated the record with an intent thereby to save or knowing it to be likely that he would thereby save Chauhan from legal punishment.

arguments.claim: Acquittal of Chauhan for abetment under s.218/109 does not exonerate or affect conviction of appellant under s.218

anchor.surface_text: Nor can we accept the contention that the acquittal of Chauhan for the abetment of the offence under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code committed by,the appellant affects the conviction of the appellant under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code.

arguments.claim: s.42 Police Act applies only to prosecutions for acts done under Police Act or general police powers, not to IPC s.218

anchor.surface_text: The period of three months prescribed for Commencing a prosecution under this section is, only with respect to prosecution of a person for something done or intended to be done by him under the provisions of the Police Act or under general Police powers given by the Act, Section 42 does not apply to prosecution against any person for anything done under the provisions of any other Act

arguments.claim: s.36 Police Act provides that nothing precludes prosecution under other Acts even for higher punishment

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 36 nothing contained in the Police, Act shall be construed to prevent any per-son from being prosecuted under any Regulation or Act for any offence made punishable by this Act or for being liable under any other Regulation or Act or any other or higher penalty-or punishment than is provided for such offence by this Act.

arguments.claim: Sentence should be reduced as Head Constable was only a tool in hands of superior officer

anchor.surface_text: An appeal is made for the reduction of the sentence on the ground that the Head Conatable was only a tool in the hands of a superior officer who might have been approached by Chauhan.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: mething done or intended to be done by him under the provisions of the Police Act or under general Police powers given by the Act, Section 42 does num

arguments.court_reasoning: No evidence of superior dictation; direct approach possible; manipulation of records undermines investigation, requires deterrent punishment

arguments.claim: No direct or substantial evidence connecting accused including Chauhan with deaths of Ramdeo and Chhotey

anchor.surface_text: From the foregoing facts found the learned Judge came to the conclusion that there was no direct or substantial evidence of any kind connecting any of the five accused, including Chauhan, with the death of Ramdeo and Chhotey.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: . Nor can we accept the companytention that the acquittal of Chauhan for the abetment of the offence under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code companymitt

arguments.court_reasoning: Court accepts lack of direct evidence for acquittal but notes likelihood of prosecution at time of false entry

holdings.text: The conviction of the appellant under s. 218 IPC is not inconsistent with the acquittal of Chauhan.

anchor.surface_text: We,, therefore, hold that the companyviction of the appellant is number inconsistent with the acquittal of Chauhan.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intent to save from punishment assessed at time of false entry when prosecution likely; subsequent acquittal irrelevant.

holdings.text: The mere acquittal of Chauhan cannot displace the finding that the appellant manipulated the record with intent to save Chauhan from legal punishment.

anchor.surface_text: On the said facts the mere acquittal of Chauhan cannot displace the finding of the learned Judge that the appellant manipulated the record with an intent thereby to save or knowing it to be likely that he would thereby save Chauhan from legal punishment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Likelihood of prosecution existed at time of fabrication despite later acquittal.

holdings.text: If the appellant made the false entry with a view to save Chauhan from legal punishment, the mere fact that Chauhan was subsequently acquitted does not make it any the less an offence under s. 218 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: If the appellant had made the false entry in the diary and manipulated other records with a view to save Chauhan from the legal punishment that might be inflicted upon him, the mere fact that he was subsequently acquitted of the offence could not make it any the less an offence under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Offence complete upon framing incorrect record with requisite intent; outcome of beneficiary's trial immaterial.

holdings.text: The acquittal of Chauhan for abetment under s. 218/109 IPC does not exonerate or affect the conviction of the appellant under s. 218 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Nor can we accept the contention that the acquittal of Chauhan for the abetment of the offence under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code committed by,the appellant affects the conviction of the appellant under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Separate offences; abettor's acquittal does not impact principal offender's guilt.

holdings.text: Section 42 of the Police Act does not apply to prosecution for offence under s. 218 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The period of three months prescribed for Commencing a prosecution under this section is, only with respect to prosecution of a person for something done or intended to be done by him under the provisions of the Police Act or under general Police powers given by the Act, Section 42 does not apply to prosecution against any person for anything done under the provisions of any other Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.42 limited to acts under Police Act or general powers; IPC offence separate.

holdings.text: By reason of s. 36 of the Police Act, s. 42 thereof cannot apply to prosecution under s. 218 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 36 nothing contained in the Police, Act shall be construed to prevent any per-son from being prosecuted under any Regulation or Act for any offence made punishable by this Act or for being liable under any other Regulation or Act or any other or higher penalty-or punishment than is provided for such offence by this Act. This section makes it clear that the provisions of the Act including s. 42 do not preclude a person from. being prosecuted for an offence under any other Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Police Act provisions do not preclude prosecution under other laws like IPC even for higher punishment.

holdings.text: The decision of the High Court is correct.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons we hold that the decision of the High Court is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both challenges rejected; conviction and sentence upheld.

holdings.text: The crux of s. 218 IPC is that the public servant acted with intent thereby to save or knowing likely to save any person from legal punishment.

anchor.surface_text: The crux of the section so far as it is relevant to the present inquiry is that the public servant should have acted in the manner contemplated by this section with an intent thereby to save or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby save any person from legal, punishment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of elements required for offence.

holdings.text: The punishment awarded errs more on the side of leniency than otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: The punishment awarded errs more on the side of leniency than otherwise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Manipulation of records undermines investigations; requires deterrent punishment; no evidence of superior dictation.

holdings.text: The acquittal of Chauhan is not justified in the circumstances of the case.

anchor.surface_text: That apart it appears to us from the record that the acquittal of Chauhan is not justified in the circumstances of the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Observation on evidence but no appeal filed by State so cannot convict Chauhan.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons we hold that the decision of the High Court is correct.

outcome.relief_summary: Decision of the High Court is correct; conviction of the appellant under Section 218 IPC and sentence of two years rigorous imprisonment upheld
